title: Historic Cabin

images.altText: Log cabin along a gravel path in a pine forest
images.title: Historic Cabin
images.caption: Built by the CCC, this cabin serves as a reminder of Jewel Cave's rich history.

bodyText:
The Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) built this cabin between 1935 and 1939. The CCC used locally sourced ponderosa pine to build the cabin and other structures. The cabin included a living room, kitchen, and a bedroom for the resident ranger and family. After completion, this cabin served as the park headquarters and was the first stop as visitors arrived to tour Jewel Cave.

Over the years, the cabin and surrounding area were modified to fit the needs of a monument with growing popularity. Eventually, visitation exceeded what the current facilities could support. In 1972, the modern visitor center opened, and the cabin was no longer needed except as a meeting place for tours through the historic entrance. The cabin now serves as a reminder of the great work completed by the CCC and the rangers who followed.
audioDescription: A three room log cabin, made of dark colored ponderosa pine, with a covered porch. The cabin sits along the edge of a canyon rim surrounded by pine trees. Inside, a stone fireplace and log mantle are seen in the main room. The kitchen has a white wood stove and natural wood cabinets. The third room, the bedroom, has wooden floors and a sink installed next to the door.

quickFacts.value: 1 mile West of the Jewel Cave Visitor Center
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: Built by the CCC, this cabin served as the first park headquarters at Jewel Cave.
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Historic Entrance
listingDescription: This is the original entrance to Jewel Cave used by rangers and visitors alike until 1972 when the modern Visitor Center and elevators opened. The Historic Entrance is still used for access to the Historic Lantern Tour and is currently the only known natural entrance to Jewel Cave.

images.altText: Ranger standing in front of opening in limestone cliff.
images.title: Historic Cave Entrance
images.caption: Rangers wear historic uniforms for the Historic Lantern Tour.

bodyText: In 1900, Frank and Albert Michaud found a small hole blowing cold air out in Hell Canyon. After enlarging the hole, the Michaud brothers discovered the beauty of what is now called Jewel Cave. The brothers developed the cave and began to offer tours to visitors. Word spread of this amazing find, and in 1908 Jewel Cave became a National Monument. It wasn't until the 1930s that Jewel Cave came under the management of the National Park Service, but it has been protected by various groups since it's discovery. Now, over 100 years later, visitors can still take a tour through the very opening enlarged by the Michaud brothers to follow their first footsteps into the darkness of Jewel Cave.
audioDescription: A metal gate with horizontal bars covers an opening in the limestone cliff.

quickFacts.value: A quarter mile walk from the parking lot of the Historic Area.
quickFacts.name: Location

quickFacts.value: The original entrance to Jewel Cave and currently the only known natural entrance.
quickFacts.name: Significance

title: Jewel Cave National Monument Park Store
listingDescription: Jewel Cave National Monument Park Store

images.title: Jewel Cave National Monument Park Store
images.caption: The park store at Jewel Cave National Monument.

bodyText: The park store is operated by Black Hills Parks and Forests Association, an official non-profit partner of the National Park Service dedicated to supporting the educational mission of Jewel Cave National Monument. The park store has a wide range of educational products and services available for retail sale. These products complement the interpretive themes you experience when visiting the park. The park store is located inside the visitor center, or you can visit the online park store at www.blackhillsparks.org.
audioDescription: The park store at Jewel Cave National Monument is located inside the Visitor Center and operated by the Black Hills Parks and Forests Association. Entering the store you will find a selection of books, clothes, stuffed animals and souvenirs for purchase. The store offers a variety of interpretive materials about Jewel Cave, the Black Hills, and the people who settled and live here.
managedByOrg: Black Hills Parks and Forests Association

title: Jewel Cave Visitor Center
listingDescription: Begin your visit to the monument at the visitor center where there is an information desk, park store, exhibits, drinking fountain, restrooms, a theater for the park film, and elevators for the Scenic Tour and the Discovery Tour. The visitor center hours, kiosk, theater, and tour times vary by season.

images.altText: "Jewel Cave National Monument" There is a red multicolored map on the wall.
images.title: Jewel Cave Map
images.caption: Visitors can learn about cave exploration in the Visitor Center.

bodyText: Begin your visit to the monument at the visitor center where there is an information desk, park store, drinking fountain, restrooms, a theater for the park film, and elevators for the Scenic Tour and the Discovery Tour. While here, be sure to explore the exciting exhibits highlighting surface features of the monument and the beautiful formations that give Jewel Cave its name. The visitor center hours, kiosk, theater, and tour times vary by season. For more information, visit Operating Hours and Seasons.
audioDescription: The brick visitor center is located below the parking lot and is accessible by a ramp or stairs. The building is entered through glass double doors. Restrooms located at the northern end of the building are entered through double glass doors. The Visitor Center has a large central tower towards the back of the building, public access is a single level with exhibits, an information desk, park store, and elevators.

quickFacts.value: The visitor center is located below the parking lot and is accessible by a ramp or stairs.
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Park Theater
listingDescription: Open seasonally, the park theater offers seating for approximately 30 people. Throughout the summer, the 23-minute park movie, "Discovery in the Darkness", is played at scheduled times. The park theater may be used for other special events or programs throughout the year.

images.altText: Chairs in front of a tv in grey room
images.title: Park Theater
images.caption: The theater can seat approximately 30 people at any given time.

bodyText: Open seasonally, the park theater offers seating for approximately 30 people. Throughout the summer, the 23-minute park movie, "Discovery in the Darkness", is played at scheduled times. Viewers will follow volunteer cave explorers into one of the last frontiers and witness some dramatic underground scenery. This movie shares the natural and cultural history of the "jewel" of the National Park Service. The park theater may be used for other special events or programs throughout the year.
audioDescription: A brick building will an accessible door.

quickFacts.value: Located down the stairs from the parking lot next to the Visitor Center
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Ticket Kiosk
listingDescription: Ranger guided cave tours are required for access to Jewel Cave and all visitors who participate in a tour must have a ticket. Tickets are sold on-site at the Ticket Kiosk on a first come first serve basis on the day of the tour. Tickets are limited by tour type, and tours often sell out by mid to late morning during the summer season (May through September).

images.altText: People wait in line at a small brick building
images.title: Visitors at Ticket Kiosk
images.caption: The summer season is busy and tickets often sell out by mid-morning.

bodyText:
Ranger guided cave tours are required for access to Jewel Cave and all visitors who participate in a tour must have a ticket.

Due to limited space on each cave tour, advanced ticket reservations are highly recommended. In collaboration with Recreation.gov, Jewel Cave National Monument offers advanced ticket sales for a majority of cave tours. Advanced sales are offered for all cave tours and are offered for the scheduled times. Please be advised that tour times and tour availability change throughout the year due to visitation and available staffing.

Visitors can purchase tour tickets on Recreation.gov up until noon the day before the tour in the slow season, and know throughout the summer booking can close quicker if the tours sell out. All financial transactions with reservations are administered by Recreation.gov. Using reservations available on recreation.gov and making a reservation is strongly recommended. Availability of walk-up tickets is not guaranteed.

If staffing is available to provide additional tours, some tickets are sold on-site at the Ticket Kiosk on a first come first serve basis on the day of the tour and are limited by tour type. Tours often sell out by mid to late morning during the summer season (May through September). During the peak season or a holiday weekend, it is advised that visitors arrive in the early morning to purchase on-site tickets. Arriving 30 minutes to an hour before the tour time may mean you arrive after that tour is already sold out. During the off-season (October through April), tickets may be sold in the Visitor Center. Learn more about tour times at Operating Hours & Seasons. To learn more about purchasing tickets in advance and tours, go to Guided Tours.
audioDescription: This red brick building is 6 sided with two ticket windows.

quickFacts.value: At the end of the main Parking Lot
quickFacts.name: Location
